barriers_other: In working with researchers who use qualitative/ethnographic methods, the main barrier is researchers' feeling like they are being asked to comply with a rather monolithic version of open science, one that focuses primarily on the openness of research materials and/or that draws on reproducibility-focused understandings of transparency; these are not idea(l)s that they identify with. There is also a sense that the socio-technical infrastructure currently available to support open science has not been built with qualitative/interpretivist research in mind, and does not operate on the community governance principles that are so important in these research communities. If I am to 'sell' open science to these researchers, one of the biggest missing pieces is the lack of a culture/discourse of data sharing and reuse; absent such a culture/discourse, it is hard for researchers to wrap their heads around why they are being asked to be 'open' in particular ways. There is also a lack of technical understanding about the FAIR data principles, which are typically also understood as a monolithic notion, and often equated with 'open science' or otherwise which focus on human-centric operationalizations of the F/A/I/R -- which is not really what the creators of this set of principles had in mind. On the support side, it often feels silly that we are asking researchers to draw up data management plans explaining how they will make their data 'open' and 'FAIR', and yet our university template is a static, proprietary .docx document and we lack infrastructure for making our own support-oriented practices more open and FAIR.
support_researchers: The researchers I support span a wide spectrum, from those who conduct deep ethnographic to those who use sophisticated data-scraping tools to conduct large scale analyses. In general, the latter group tends to be more enthusiastic about sharing their data than the former.
uni_support_other: The biggest thing the university could do to help research be more open is focus on cultivating a university-wide vision for open science that everybody can see themselves reflected in, regardless of discipline, method, epistemological commitments, etc. One way of doing this could be to work with researchers, support staff, policy officers, etc. in individual institutes to develop an Open Science statement that builds up from their domain-specific practices and commitments. This will be especially important if there is an expectation that units will be evaluated based on their open science activities at some future moment, and will thus help ensure that any such evaluation is rooted in the norms and practices of the field itself, rather than in some extant domain. The university vision can then be refined based on the input of the individual institutes.
oscl_support_other: My impression that OSCL is doing well at engaging the research community. Inevitably there is a selection effect in that those engaging with OSCL already see value in the agenda it promotes. There will of course be folks (or entire fields) who don't see that value, but I'm not sure that this is something an entity like OSCL can really do much about for the time being. Getting back to my earlier comment, I think just remaining 'open' to different versions/enactment of open science will serve any entity well if it wishes to broaden its community-base, but with the expectation that not everyone from every field will show up at the same time.
